intro: Silene cerastoides subsp. tridentata, commonly known as the three-toothed catchfly, is a flowering plant native to North America. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has three prominent tooth-like lobes on its leaves, which give it its common name. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in open habitats such as prairies and disturbed areas. Silene cerastoides subsp. tridentata is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, known for its showy flowers and succulent-like stems.
